values.description:
ign-rendering will now compile and link against ogre and optix libraries only if they exist.

There must be at least one rendering engine available otherwise cmake will output a build error

I also modified `FindOptiX.cmake` to search in a path defined by the env variable `OPTIX_INSTALL_DIR` - just a convenience thing.
values.title: Make ogre and optix optional dependencies

summary.raw:
ign-rendering will now compile and link against ogre and optix libraries only if they exist.

There must be at least one rendering engine available otherwise cmake will output a build error

I also modified `FindOptiX.cmake` to search in a path defined by the env variable `OPTIX_INSTALL_DIR` - just a convenience thing.
summary.html:
ign-rendering will now compile and link against ogre and optix libraries only if they exist.

There must be at least one rendering engine available otherwise cmake will output a build error

I also modified FindOptiX.cmake to search in a path defined by the env variable OPTIX_INSTALL_DIR - just a convenience thing.

values.title: Fix building examples on Ubuntu Xenial

values.description:
The examples were being built by default, but they use find_package(ignition-rendering0 REQUIRED). This causes the first build of ignition-rendering to fail because the examples are built before the ignition-rendering cmake config file is installed. This PR makes the examples separate cmake projects and disables building them by default.

Without this PR the only way I can get igntion-rendering to build is to comment out `add_subdirectory(examples)`, run `make`, run `make install`, uncomment, and then run `make`. From then on `make` works as long as I don't uninstall.
values.title: Make examples separate cmake projects

summary.raw:
The examples were being built by default, but they use find_package(ignition-rendering0 REQUIRED). This causes the first build of ignition-rendering to fail because the examples are built before the ignition-rendering cmake config file is installed. This PR makes the examples separate cmake projects and disables building them by default.

Without this PR the only way I can get igntion-rendering to build is to comment out `add_subdirectory(examples)`, run `make`, run `make install`, uncomment, and then run `make`. From then on `make` works as long as I don't uninstall.
summary.html:
The examples were being built by default, but they use find_package(ignition-rendering0 REQUIRED). This causes the first build of ignition-rendering to fail because the examples are built before the ignition-rendering cmake config file is installed. This PR makes the examples separate cmake projects and disables building them by default.

Without this PR the only way I can get igntion-rendering to build is to comment out add_subdirectory(examples), run make, run make install, uncomment, and then run make. From then on make works as long as I don't uninstall.

values.description:
Finish implementing OgreRTShaderSystem and ported rtshader media resources from gazebo. This enables shadows in ogre render engine, e.g. to test, run `custom_scene_viewer` example and switch to a scene with objects in it to see shadows cast on the ground plane.

Also pimpl'ized OgreRTShaderSystem class

Added `IGN_RENDERING_RESOURCE_PATH` which is used by 

  * optix to look for compiled ptx files and 

  * ogre to look for rtshader files

Added shadows integration test

TODO

  * support user specified paths for locating media resources
values.title: Add Ogre rtshaderlib and enable shadows

summary.raw:
Finish implementing OgreRTShaderSystem and ported rtshader media resources from gazebo. This enables shadows in ogre render engine, e.g. to test, run `custom_scene_viewer` example and switch to a scene with objects in it to see shadows cast on the ground plane.

Also pimpl'ized OgreRTShaderSystem class

Added `IGN_RENDERING_RESOURCE_PATH` which is used by 

  * optix to look for compiled ptx files and 

  * ogre to look for rtshader files

Added shadows integration test

TODO

  * support user specified paths for locating media resources
summary.html:
Finish implementing OgreRTShaderSystem and ported rtshader media resources from gazebo. This enables shadows in ogre render engine, e.g. to test, run custom_scene_viewer example and switch to a scene with objects in it to see shadows cast on the ground plane.

Also pimpl'ized OgreRTShaderSystem class

Added IGN_RENDERING_RESOURCE_PATH which is used by

  • optix to look for compiled ptx files and

  • ogre to look for rtshader files

Added shadows integration test

TODO

  • support user specified paths for locating media resources

values.description: If xwininfo is installed, but glxinfo is not, then CheckDRIDisplay will attempt to call a script called `tools/gl-test.py`.  This tool doesn't currently exist, so the check fails with obscure cmake errors.  Import the script from gazebo to make sure this fallback works.
values.title: Add the gl-test tool.

summary.raw: If xwininfo is installed, but glxinfo is not, then CheckDRIDisplay will attempt to call a script called `tools/gl-test.py`.  This tool doesn't currently exist, so the check fails with obscure cmake errors.  Import the script from gazebo to make sure this fallback works.
summary.html: If xwininfo is installed, but glxinfo is not, then CheckDRIDisplay will attempt to call a script called tools/gl-test.py. This tool doesn't currently exist, so the check fails with obscure cmake errors. Import the script from gazebo to make sure this fallback works.

values.description:
This fixes a crash we are seeing in Delphyne during initialization.

The problem was introduced between changesets 215 and 217 (215 works, 217 does not).  I did some debugging, and I found that what was happening was that a nullptr was being passed into `OgreRTShaderSystem::AttachViewport()`, and then being dereferenced, causing the crash.  In changeset 215 and earlier, this didn't happen because the "initialized" check at the start of `AttachViewport()` returned false.  In the new code, apparently `IsInitialized()` returns true, leading to this crash.  Adding this nullptr check seems to fix the problem for me, but it may not be the "right" solution, so consider this an RFC.
values.title: Check to make sure the scene isn't nullptr before dereferencing.

summary.raw:
This fixes a crash we are seeing in Delphyne during initialization.

The problem was introduced between changesets 215 and 217 (215 works, 217 does not).  I did some debugging, and I found that what was happening was that a nullptr was being passed into `OgreRTShaderSystem::AttachViewport()`, and then being dereferenced, causing the crash.  In changeset 215 and earlier, this didn't happen because the "initialized" check at the start of `AttachViewport()` returned false.  In the new code, apparently `IsInitialized()` returns true, leading to this crash.  Adding this nullptr check seems to fix the problem for me, but it may not be the "right" solution, so consider this an RFC.
summary.html:
This fixes a crash we are seeing in Delphyne during initialization.

The problem was introduced between changesets 215 and 217 (215 works, 217 does not). I did some debugging, and I found that what was happening was that a nullptr was being passed into OgreRTShaderSystem::AttachViewport(), and then being dereferenced, causing the crash. In changeset 215 and earlier, this didn't happen because the "initialized" check at the start of AttachViewport() returned false. In the new code, apparently IsInitialized() returns true, leading to this crash. Adding this nullptr check seems to fix the problem for me, but it may not be the "right" solution, so consider this an RFC.

values.description:
tl;dr:

You  can now create a RenderWindow with `optix`.

long version:

I started abstracting the RenderWindow class a bit more.  Optix doesn't have a convenient class for attaching to the external windowing system like ogre (implementation is platform-specific code, e.g. searches for xwindow / xdisplay, and cocoa window on OSX, etc) . So in optix's RenderWindow implementation, I'm mocking it using  a render texture.  I've updated the `RenderTarget_TEST` to take in `optix` render engine, and now it shouldn't crash.

I've also refactored ogre's `CreateRenderWindow` implementation. There was a problem with null `_scene` pointer in RTShaderSystem as identified in pull request #29. This should not happen any more. Updated `Scene_Test` to test creating a render window.
values.title: Mock render window for optix

summary.raw:
tl;dr:

You  can now create a RenderWindow with `optix`.

long version:

I started abstracting the RenderWindow class a bit more.  Optix doesn't have a convenient class for attaching to the external windowing system like ogre (implementation is platform-specific code, e.g. searches for xwindow / xdisplay, and cocoa window on OSX, etc) . So in optix's RenderWindow implementation, I'm mocking it using  a render texture.  I've updated the `RenderTarget_TEST` to take in `optix` render engine, and now it shouldn't crash.

I've also refactored ogre's `CreateRenderWindow` implementation. There was a problem with null `_scene` pointer in RTShaderSystem as identified in pull request #29. This should not happen any more. Updated `Scene_Test` to test creating a render window.
summary.html:
tl;dr:

You can now create a RenderWindow with optix.

long version:

I started abstracting the RenderWindow class a bit more. Optix doesn't have a convenient class for attaching to the external windowing system like ogre (implementation is platform-specific code, e.g. searches for xwindow / xdisplay, and cocoa window on OSX, etc) . So in optix's RenderWindow implementation, I'm mocking it using a render texture. I've updated the RenderTarget_TEST to take in optix render engine, and now it shouldn't crash.

I've also refactored ogre's CreateRenderWindow implementation. There was a problem with null _scene pointer in RTShaderSystem as identified in pull request #29. This should not happen any more. Updated Scene_Test to test creating a render window.

values.description:
This is part of a GPU lidar for ignition sensors.

It adds vertex and fragment shader support. Shaders can be given float and integer `uniform` parameters. Cameras also have a method for setting a material that they  will see on all objects. This allows creating a camera that sees all objects with a shader that encodes depth in the color output.

Only Ogre is supported.
values.title: Custom shaders on all objects seen by a camera

summary.raw:
This is part of a GPU lidar for ignition sensors.

It adds vertex and fragment shader support. Shaders can be given float and integer `uniform` parameters. Cameras also have a method for setting a material that they  will see on all objects. This allows creating a camera that sees all objects with a shader that encodes depth in the color output.

Only Ogre is supported.
summary.html:
This is part of a GPU lidar for ignition sensors.

It adds vertex and fragment shader support. Shaders can be given float and integer uniform parameters. Cameras also have a method for setting a material that they will see on all objects. This allows creating a camera that sees all objects with a shader that encodes depth in the color output.

Only Ogre is supported.

values.description:
There was an inconsistence in `config.cmake` when using ign-math4, since it had ign-math3 hardcoded.

I propose we follow what other libraries have been doing and support a single math version for now.

I didn't put effort into making the solution elegant since this will be overridden by the change to ign-cmake which is coming soon anyway.

Also added an example build to pipelines to make sure this is working.

Merging this will help ign-gui.
values.title: Depend on Math 4 only

summary.raw:
There was an inconsistence in `config.cmake` when using ign-math4, since it had ign-math3 hardcoded.

I propose we follow what other libraries have been doing and support a single math version for now.

I didn't put effort into making the solution elegant since this will be overridden by the change to ign-cmake which is coming soon anyway.

Also added an example build to pipelines to make sure this is working.

Merging this will help ign-gui.
summary.html:
There was an inconsistence in config.cmake when using ign-math4, since it had ign-math3 hardcoded.

I propose we follow what other libraries have been doing and support a single math version for now.

I didn't put effort into making the solution elegant since this will be overridden by the change to ign-cmake which is coming soon anyway.

Also added an example build to pipelines to make sure this is working.

Merging this will help ign-gui.

values.description:
support for `compute_20` gpu architecture was deprecated in CUDA 8 and removed from CUDA 9.

Removing the NV flags fixes the build.
values.title: Fix ign-rendering-optix build against CUDA 9.0

summary.raw:
support for `compute_20` gpu architecture was deprecated in CUDA 8 and removed from CUDA 9.

Removing the NV flags fixes the build.
summary.html:
support for compute_20 gpu architecture was deprecated in CUDA 8 and removed from CUDA 9.

Removing the NV flags fixes the build.

values.description:
Without this forward declare, if you build with `-DENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION=false` the cmake configure fails with:

```
CMake Error at src/CMakeLists.txt:41 (ign_build_dri_tests):
  Unknown CMake command "ign_build_dri_tests".


-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
```
values.title: add missing 'forward-declare' of ign_build_dri_tests macro
